item.title: Tables for Feb 3-5
item.description: Here’s the Table Teams map for this week (Feb 3 and Feb 5 classes):

item.title: Readings for Week 6
item.description:
Updates

  • Class 8 Slides

  • CS Distinguished Speaker: Matthew Jagielski, Anthropic. ML Security Research in the Era of Agentic Systems, Friday, 13 February, 11:00am-noon, Rice 540.

  • Project Mini-Proposals are due Monday, 16 February (11:59pm). See the assignment in Canvas. The Overleaf Template provides a template for what is expected in your proposal: [PDF Link].

Reading for Thursday, 12 February (repeated from Readings for Week 4):

  • Milad Nasr, Javier Rando, Nicholas Carlini, Jonathan Hayase, Matthew Jagielski, A. Feder Cooper, Daphne Ippolito, Christopher A. Choquette-Choo, Florian Tramèr, and Katherine Lee. Scalable extraction of training data from aligned, production language models. In International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR) 2025. ICLR Web Link. (You can also see the review discussion: ICLR Forum)

One of the authors of this paper, Matthew Jagielski (now at Anthropic), will visit UVA on Friday, 13 February and give a Distinguished Talk at 11:00am Friday, 13 February, in Rice 540.

item.title: Readings for Week 5
item.description:
Updates

  • The blogs for Class 5 and Class 6 are now posted.
  • Every project team should have received feedback on your Project Idea. The next main deliverable for the project is your Project Mini-Proposal, which is due Monday, 16 February. (This will be discussed in class on Tuesday.)

Reading for Tuesday, 10 February (repeated from Readings for Week 4)

  • Cynthia Rudin. Stop explaining black box machine learning models for high stakes decisions and use interpretable models instead. Nature Machine Intelligence, May 2019. [PDF Link] [arXiv version] (less nicely formatted, but with fixed equations)

Reading for Thursday, 12 February:

  • Milad Nasr, Javier Rando, Nicholas Carlini, Jonathan Hayase, Matthew Jagielski, A. Feder Cooper, Daphne Ippolito, Christopher A. Choquette-Choo, Florian Tramèr, and Katherine Lee. Scalable extraction of training data from aligned, production language models. In International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR) 2025. ICLR Web Link. (You can also see the review discussion: ICLR Forum)

One of the authors of this paper, Matthew Jagielski (now at Anthropic), will visit UVA on Friday, 13 February and give a Distinguished Talk at 11:00am Friday, 13 February, in Rice 540.

item.title: Readings for Week 4
item.description:
Clinical use of AI in Medicine

Reading for Tuesday, 3 February (repeated from Previous Post, but with date updated due to snow day):

  • Ethan Goh, Robert J. Gallo, Eric Strong, Yingjie Weng, Hannah Kerman, Jason A. Freed, Joséphine A. Cool, Zahir Kanjee, Kathleen P. Lane, Andrew S. Parsons, Neera Ahuja, Eric Horvitz, Daniel Yang, Arnold Milstein, Andrew P. J. Olson, Jason Hom, Jonathan H. Chen and Adam Rodman. GPT-4 assistance for improvement of physician performance on patient care tasks: a randomized controlled trial. Nature Medicine, February 2025. [PDF Link] [Web Link]

AI Bias and Interpretability

Our next main topic, which will be for the Thursday, 5 February and Tuesday, 10 February, is on biases in AI systems and how to measure and mitigate them. There is already a vast literature on this topic, and entire courses and research agendas focused on it, so we will only see a small slice of it in these two class (and may have more classes later that go in more depth or touch on other aspects).

item.title: Blog for Class 4 Posted
item.description: The blog for Class 4 is now posted: Class 4 Blog: Data Centers / AI 2027 and AI as Normal Technology. Thanks to Team 10 for writing the blog post, and to Team 2 for presenting the News and Team 6 for leading the topic.

item.title: Tables for Jan 29
item.description:
Here’s the Table Teams map for Jan 29:

Instead of sitting in your “Table Teams”, the teams that are not presenting or blogging today will sit in your discussion groups so you have a chance to meet the people in your on-line discussion in person.

item.title: Class 4
item.description:
Slides

Class 4 Slides (PDF)

Schedule

Due Sunday, 11:59pm: Project Team Form (assigned in Canvas) to submit your ideal project teammates and topic idea. Everyone should submit this — if you have not formed a team or identified a topic yet that is fine, but you should still submit the form, and we will use these to assemble project teams.

Check the Team Schedule to be sure you know your Table Team’s upcoming responbilities, and Readings for Next Week. In the likely event of a snow day next week, we’ll adjust the schedule, but for now assume we’ll have class normally on Tuesday.

item.title: Readings for Week 3
item.description:
Instructions for the Class Blogs are here. Blogging teams should submit a PR with the class blog no later than 5 days after the class (with an expectation that it will be posted on the course site within one week of the class). News and Lead teams should share any materials with the Blog team right after the class.

Readings for Tuesday, 27 January:

  • John Jumper, Richard Evans, Alexander Pritzel, Tim Green, Michael Figurnov, Olaf Ronneberger, Kathryn Tunyasuvunakool, Russ Bates, Augustin Žídek, Anna Potapenko, Alex Bridgland, Clemens Meyer, Simon A. A. Kohl, Andrew J. Ballard, Andrew Cowie, Bernardino Romera-Paredes, Stanislav Nikolov, Rishub Jain, Jonas Adler, Trevor Back, Stig Petersen, David Reiman, Ellen Clancy, Michal Zielinski, Martin Steinegger, Michalina Pacholska, Tamas Berghammer, Sebastian Bodenstein, David Silver, Oriol Vinyals, Andrew W. Senior, Koray Kavukcuoglu, Pushmeet Kohli, and Demis Hassabis. Highly accurate protein structure prediction with AlphaFold. Nature, 26 August 2021.
    [PDF Link]
    Optional: There is an “AlphaFold 3” now, described in this paper, but you are not expected to read this one.

item.title: Class 3
item.description:
Slides

Class 3 Slides (PDF)

Schedule

Check the Team Schedule to be sure you know your Table Team’s upcoming responbilities, and Readings for Thursday.

Please don’t wait for any further prodding to dicuss the Thursday readings. You should be able to create discussion posts in your discussion group, and go ahead and do this with your thoughts on the paper you read. Feel free to also continue the discussion from anything that come up in today’s class in your on-line discussion group.

item.title: Tables for Week 2
item.description: Here’s the Table Teams map for this week (both 20 Jan and 22 Jan classes):

item.title: Class 2
item.description:
Slides

Class 2 Slides (PDF)

Schedule

You should be in one of the on-line discussion groups now, and should have received (or will soon receive) a message from your TA to start discussion there.

Check the Team Schedule to be sure you know your Table Team’s upcoming responbilities, and Readings for Week 2.

Links

I’ve talked about several of the themes from today in other places. You can see videos from a 2014 cs4414: Operating Systems course here: Invent the Future! (that talk was in 2014 and I make some predictions targeting the 15-year future in 2029, so we’re getting pretty close to see how badly I did…) A more recent version is: Jobs for Humans, 2030-2045 from TEDxChantilly.

item.title: Readings for Week 2
item.description:
Reading for Tuesday, 20 January:

  • Dario Amodei (CEO and co-founder of Anthropic), Machines of Loving Grace: How AI Could Transform the World for the Better. October 2024 [PDF Link]

Readings for Thursday, 22 January:

Lead team should read both of the papers below and plan to talk about both of them. Other students can select one of the two papers to read (and are, of course, welcome to read both of them, but only expected to read and be able to discuss one of the two papers).

item.title: Class 1
item.description:
Slides

Class 1 Slides (PDF)

Schedule

By 8:29 PM tonight (13 January 2026) everyone who wants to be in the class should submit the Starting the Course Survey in Canvas: [Canvas Link].

We will make team assignments for your table teams and on-line discussion groups based on the survey submissions, and aim to have these ready by tomorrow.

Readings for Thursday, 15 January:

  • Neil deGrasse Tyson, Science’s Endless Golden Age. Published in The Invisible Future: the seamless integration of technology into everday life, edited by Peter J. Denning, November 2001. [PDF Link]

item.title: Preliminary Syllabus Posted
item.description: A preliminary syllabus is now available. This should give you a good idea what to expect in the class, but some aspects may change and more details will be added before the semester begins.

item.title: Welcome
item.description:
This is a preliminary website for the cs4501: AI and Humanity course to be offered in Spring 2026.

More information will be posted soon, but feel free to contact me (evans@virginia.edu) with any questions about the course.

Meetings: Tuesdays and Thursdays, 9:30-10:45am in Olsson 018.

Official Prerequisite: Completed CS 2100 (DSA1) with a grade of C- or better. (I will make exceptions to this if you have an interest in taking the class and have sufficient background in computing.)
